desc: f(x)=x-xe^{-1/x} show f(x) is increasing on (0,infty) and lim_{x->infty} f(x)=1
problem:
\begin{problem*}{}{}
  Solve the following:
  \begin{enumerate}[(a)]
    \item Let $f(x)=x-xe^{-\frac 1x}, \ \ x>0$. Show that
      $f(x)$ is an increasing function on $(0,\infty)$,
      and $\lim_{x\to\infty} f(x)=1$.

    \item Using part (a) or otherwise, draw graphs of
      $y=x-1, y=x, y=x+1$, and $y=xe^{-\frac{1}{|x|}}$
      for $-\infty<x<\infty$ using the same $X$ and $Y$ axes.
  \end{enumerate}
\end{problem*}
